{{primary sources|date=December 2009}}
'''ACROSS''' is a Singular Strategic R&D Project led by Treelogic<ref>[http://www.treelogic.com Treelogic]</ref> funded by the Spanish Ministry of Industry, Tourism and Trade<ref>[http://www.mityc.es Spanish Ministry of Industry, Tourism and Trade] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091207090817/http://www7.mityc.es/ |date=2009-12-07 }} through the Plan Avanza I+D initiative. ACROSS carries out [[research and development]]</ref> activities in the field of [[Robotics]] and [[Cognitive informatics|Cognitive Computing]] over an execution time-frame from 2009 to 2011. ACROSS project involves a number higher than 100 researchers from 13 Spanish entities.
== ACROSS project objectives == ACROSS modifies the design of [[social robot]]ics, blocked in providing predefined services, going further by means of [[Artificial intelligence|intelligent systems]]. These systems are able to self-reconfigure and modify their behavior autonomously through the capacity for understanding, learning and software [[Virtual private network|remote access]].
In order to provide an open framework for collaboration between universities, [[research center]]s and the Administration, ACROSS develops Open Source Services available to everybody.
== Three application domains == ACROSS works in three [[application domain]]s:
* Autonomous living: robots are used as technological tools to help handicapped person into daily tasks. * Psycho-Affective Disorders ([[autism]]): robots are used to mitigate [[cognitive disorder]]s. * Marketing: robots are used to interact with humans in a [[recreation]]al approach.
== Consortium == * Treelogic * Alimerka * Bizintek * Universitat Politécnica de Catalunya * [[University of Deusto]] * European Centre for Soft Computing * Fatronik - {{Interlanguage link multi|Tecnalia|es}} * Fundació Hospital Comarcal Sant Antoni Abat * Fundación Pública Andaluza para la Gestión de la Investigación en Salud de Sevilla, "Virgen del Rocío" University Hospitals * m-BOT * Omicron Electronic * [http://robolab.unex.es Universidad de Extremadura - RoboLab] * Verbio Technologies

Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=73}} * Non-specified number of plain-clothed officiers from the NSA, Criminal Investigations Department and BDF Intelligence{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=73}} |numpart = |dfens = |dfen = |footage = }}
{{Campaignbox Bahraini uprising}}
'''Bahrain's Bloody Thursday''' ({{lang-ar|خميس البحرين الدامي}}) is the name given by protesters in [[Bahrain]] to 17 February 2011, the fourth day of their [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|national uprising]]. [[Public Security Forces|Bahrain security forces]] launched a [[pre-dawn raid]] to clear [[Pearl Roundabout]] in [[Manama]] of the protesters camped there, most of whom were at the time asleep in tents; four were killed and about 300 injured. The event led some to demand even more political reform than they had been before, calling for an end to the [[King of Bahrain|reign]] of King [[Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa]].
The clearance was described by witnesses as being brutal and sudden. Clouds of [[Tear Gas|tear gas]] covered the area, and volleys of [[birdshot]] were fired on those who refused to withdraw. Medics, ambulances and a journalist were reportedly attacked as well. Sporadic clashes broke out around Bahrain hours after the raid. During the afternoon the [[National Guard (Bahrain)|National Guard]] and [[Bahrain Defence Force|army]] deployed armoured vehicles, tanks, more than 50 armoured personnel carriers and set up checkpoints in the streets around the country. Protesters then took refuge at [[Salmaniya Medical Complex]] and continued their agitations; thousands of them chanted "Down with the king, down with the government."
The [[Cabinet of Bahrain|government]] accused protesters of attacking the security forces, 50 of whom sustained injuries, and insisted that action had been necessary to pull Bahrain back from the "brink of a sectarian abyss".<ref name="AJE LB 17.2.2011"/> But [[Opposition (Bahrain)|opposition parties]] dismissed the government's account as a "silly play",<ref name="Al wasat 19"/> described the raid as a "heinous massacre"{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=75}} and submitted their resignations from the [[National Assembly of Bahrain|lower house]] of [[Council of Representatives of Bahrain|Parliament]].
Internationally, the [[Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf|Gulf Cooperation Council]] Ministers of Foreign Affairs expressed their solidarity with government of Bahrain and their support for the measures taken. The [[United Nations]], the [[European Union]] and the [[United States]] on the other hand expressed their deep concern and regret for the violence used against protesters. The [[UK|United Kingdom]] government announced that in light of the unrest it would revoke some arms export licences to Bahrain. A number of international rights groups and independent observers criticised the government crackdown.
==Background==
{{Further|Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|Background of the Bahraini uprising (2011–present)}}
[[File:Protesters gathering in Pearl roundabout.jpg|thumb|Protesters gathering at Pearl Roundabout for the first time on 15 February.]] [[File:Police north of Pearl Roundabout.jpg|thumb|Police retreated from Pearl Roundabout to the northern area close to [[Bahrain City Centre]]]]
The events were one of a string of [[Arab Spring|protests]] that occurred across the [[Arab world]] following the self-immolation and eventual death of [[Mohammed Bouazizi]] in [[2010–2011 Tunisian protests|Tunisia]], the majority [[Shia]] population of Bahrain, as well as some [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] Muslims, took to the streets demanding reforms.<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb">{{cite news | title = Bahrain Activists in 'Day of Rage | date = 14 February 2011 | publisher = Al Jazeera | url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011214925802473.html | accessdate = 20 September 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110410201125/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011214925802473.html | archivedate = 10 April 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> [[Al Jazeera]] reported that a protest was planned for 14 February,<ref name="aljaz_febdominos">{{cite news|title=Calls for Weekend Protests in Syria |date=4 February 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |accessdate=31 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wLygnerq?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |archivedate=8 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> just a few months after the controversial [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 2010|2010 election]].<ref name="bchr_gov_panic">{{cite press release|title=In Fear of Transmitting the Tunisian and Egyptian Demonstrations to Bahrain: Blocking a Facebook Group That Calls People To Go Down the Streets and Demonstrate Against the Authority's Policy |publisher=[[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] |date=6 February 2011 |url=http://bahrainrights.org/en/node/3721 |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wNUbTPmx?url=http://bahrainrights.org/en/node/3721 |archivedate=9 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
On 14 February (referred to as [[Day of Rage (Bahrain)|Day of Rage]] by protest organisers), about 6,000 people took part in many protests around Bahrain demanding the release of previously detained protesters,<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb"/> socio-economic justice, political reform and a constitutional monarchy. Police then attacked the protesters throughout the day, using tear gas, rubber bullets and shotguns, inflicting many injuries and causing the hospitalisation of four demonstrators.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=68–9}} In the evening, [[Death of Ali Abdulhadi Mushaima|Ali Mushaima]] died from police shotgun wounds to his back at close range.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=69, 229}} The next day, thousands of mourners attended his funeral. During the ceremony police shot [[Death of Fadhel Al-Matrook|Fadhel Al-Matrook]] in the back at close range; he died from his wounds within an hour.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=70, 229–30}} People were then allowed to march to and occupy [[Pearl Roundabout]],{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=71}} where they began to set up tents;<ref>{{cite web | author = [[Brian Murphy (writer)|Murphy, Brian]] | url = http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12918361&page=1 | title = Bahrain Square Becomes New Center for Arab Anger | agency = Associated Press | work = ABC News | date = 15 February 2011 | accessdate = 15 April 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110628222728/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=12918361&page=1 | archivedate = 28 June 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> the number of demonstrators had swelled to 10,000 people by nightfall.<ref name="Raucous Protest">{{cite news | author = [[Michael Slackman|Slackman, Michael]] | work = [[The New York Times]] | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/world/middleeast/16bahrain.html | title = Bahrain Takes the Stage with a Raucous Protest | date = 15 February 2011 | accessdate = | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170602181457/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/world/middleeast/16bahrain.html | archivedate = 2 June 2017 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> King Hamad offered his condolences for the two deaths and announced the establishment of a committee to investigate the events of the previous two days. In total, 25 people were said to have been injured on 15 February.<ref>{{cite news | author = Randeree, Bilal | url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121571645551445.html | title = Deaths Heighten Bahrain Tension | publisher = Al Jazeera | date = 15 February 2011 | accessdate = 14 April 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110405192440/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121571645551445.html | archivedate = 5 April 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
By 16 February, Pearl Roundabout was still occupied by thousands of protesters.<ref name="alj_16Feb">{{cite news|title=Bahrain Protesters Hold Ground |date=16 February 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121635518925202.html |accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wY7a5QCD?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121635518925202.html |archivedate=16 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Some of those present at the scene described the mood at the roundabout as "festive," with protesters distributing tea, coffee and food while discussing the situation in the country. Opposition political figures such as [[Ali Salman]] and [[Abdulwahab Hussain]] also addressed the crowds gathered at the roundabout. Elsewhere in the country a funeral procession was held for Fadhel Al-Matrook, while a motorcade of about 100 cars with supporters of King Hamad passed without police interference.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=72–3}}
The [[Ministry of the Interior (Bahrain)|Ministry of Interior]] then announced that the gathering at Pearl Roundabout was illegal and that it was only tolerated as a display of sympathy in the wake of recent events.<ref name="Al wasat 1">{{cite news | script-title=ar:"الداخلية": تجمع "دوار اللؤلؤة" لم يستوفِ الإجراءات القانونية | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527727/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928053130/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527727/1.html | archivedate=28 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> King Hamad visited the [[Bahrain Defence Force]] headquarters, where he met its Commander-in-Chief Field Marshal Khalifa bin Ahmad and other senior military officers. Together they reviewed "the preparations undertaken by the Defence Force to protect the security of the homeland and to maintain the safety of citizens."<ref name="Al Wasat 2">{{cite news | script-title=ar:العاهل يطلع على استعدادات قوة الدفاع لحماية أمن الوطن | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527616/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220075639/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527616/1.html | archivedate=20 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Naming===
In Bahrain, especially among the organising activists, the day police stormed the roundabout was posthumously referred to as Bahrain Bloody Thursday;<ref name="Al wasat 12">{{cite news | script-title=ar:خميس البحرين الدامي | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527793/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907032605/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527793/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="MV 19.2.2011">{{cite news | author=Hani Al-Fardan | script-title=ar:ماذا بعد الخميس الدامي؟ | date=19 February 2011 | publisher=Manama Voice | url=http://manamavoice.com/news-news_read-6526-0.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222142930/http://manamavoice.com/news-news_read-6526-0.html | archivedate=22 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | script-title=ar:الرصاص الحي يخترق رأس شاب وصدر آخر | date=19 February 2011 | work=Al Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527966/1.html | accessdate=30 July 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202024254/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527966/1.html | archivedate=2 December 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> some doctors also referred to it as '''Black Thursday''';<ref name="AJE 20.2.2011">{{cite news | author=Ben Piven and Soraya Lennie | title=A 'time for martyrs' in Bahrain | date=20 February 2011 | publisher=Al Jazeera | url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2011/02/2011220144153537485.html | accessdate=27 May 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523211223/http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2011/02/2011220144153537485.html | archivedate=23 May 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> while other opposition members have called it a massacre.<ref>{{cite news | author=Cynthia Johnston and Frederik Richter | title=Thousands join funerals after Bahrain killings | date=18 February 2011 | agency=Reuters | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/18/us-bahrain-idUSTRE71G5YP20110218 | accessdate=14 July 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920085420/http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/18/us-bahrain-idUSTRE71G5YP20110218 | archivedate=20 September 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Raid==
[[File:Police moving to Pearl Roundabout from the northern side.jpg|thumb|Three out of four police units deployed in [[Manama]] entered Pearl Roundabout from several points and pushed protesters away from it{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=73}}]]
In a pre-dawn raid, at about 3:00 on 17 February, around 1,000 police were dispatched to clear the Pearl Roundabout of an estimated 1,500–3,000<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/> individuals staying overnight in tents. According to the [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry]], police were armed with sticks, shields, sound bombs, tear gas and shotguns.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=73}} They moved on protesters from two directions, the flyover north of Pearl Roundabout and [[Noaim]], south of the roundabout.<ref name="Al wasat 23"/> In addition, personnel from NSA and BDF were onsite.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=73}}
===Eyewitness and journalist accounts===
According to eyewitnesses, the raid was sudden and without warning and many sleeping protesters, including women and children, were awoken by the sounds of tear gas and stun grenades.<ref name="Al wasat 23">{{cite news | script-title=ar:شهود عيان: هجموا علينا ونحن نائمون وداسوا بأرجلهم أجسادنا | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527881/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906100728/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527881/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Armed plainclothes policemen arrived in more than 100 civilian cars<ref name="Al wasat 23"/> and started breaking into tents before the uniformed officers started shooting. The police carried knives, which they used to slice through tents,<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(2)">{{cite news | author=Martin Chulov | title=Bahrain protests: Four killed as riot police storm Pearl Square | date=17 February 2011 | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrain-protests-riot-police-storm-pearl-square?INTCMP=SRCH | accessdate=18 January 2012 | location=London | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217142734/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrain-protests-riot-police-storm-pearl-square?INTCMP=SRCH | archivedate=17 December 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> before beating women and men inside and firing on some people with bird-shot shotguns.<ref name="AJE 17.2.2011">{{cite news | title = Bahrain deploys army after raid | date = 17 February 2011 | publisher = Al Jazeera | url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011217191751611489.html | accessdate = 17 January 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120116170452/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011217191751611489.html | archivedate = 16 January 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> Clouds of tear gas covered Pearl Roundabout that "one could not see surroundings," according to one witness.
[[Maryam Alkhawaja]] of the [[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] said: "The attack was very violent, [the police] were not showing any mercy."<ref name="AJE LB 17.2.2011">{{cite news | title = Al Jazeera Live Blog 17 February | date = 17 February 2011 | work = [[Al Jazeera]] | url = http://blogs.aljazeera.com/middle-east/2011/02/16/live-blog-bahrain#feb17 | accessdate = 17 January 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120501071021/http://blogs.aljazeera.com/middle-east/2011/02/16/live-blog-bahrain#feb17 | archivedate = 1 May 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> An unnamed injured protester told the local independent newspaper ''[[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al-Wasat]]'' he was within a group of protesters who were awake and that they chanted "peaceful ... peaceful" before being attacked by police who reportedly stole his wallet, camera and mobile phone after beating and dragging him with a rope. Another injured protester described how women and children were running all over the place; even after withdrawing to nearby villages, police still pursued protesters and arrested "large numbers" of them. Other eyewitnesses said police searched the cars parked around Pearl Roundabout, damaging some of them.<ref name="Al wasat 11">{{cite news | script-title=ar:يوم لم تعشه البحرين من قبل سالت فيه دماء أبنائها على أرصفتها | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527794/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219223522/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527794/1.html | archivedate=19 February 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#F3F0FD |salign=right| quote = People were attacked while they were sleeping. There was no warning. And when they ran, the police attacked them from the direction they fled to.| source = ''Nazeha Saeed'', [[Radio Monte Carlo]]<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb"/>|align=left| width=250px}}
Yet another injured protesters said: "They had encircled us and they kept shooting tear gas and live rounds. The circle got closer and closer."<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/> Some witnesses claimed the police used anti-Shia curses during their attacks on the mainly Shia protesters. Medics who arrived at Pearl Roundabout said they saw police stamping on handcuffed protesters who laid on the ground. A nurse said she saw a group of police "execute" a young protester with a gun at "point-blank range" after handcuffing and beating him.<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011"/>
[[File:Police surrounding 5 ambulances nearby Pearl roundabout.jpg|thumb|Five ambulances arrived at Pearl Roundabout]]
''[[ABC News]]'' reporter [[Miguel Marquez]] said he was beaten by men carrying [[Club (weapon)|clubs]] while he was making a phone call report. "There was a canister that looked like – No! No! No! Hey! I'm a journalist here! I'm going! I'm going! I'm going! I'm going! ... I'm hit." Then, in an attempt to show he was not a protester, Marquez yelled "Journalist, journalist!," yet he reported getting hit multiple times and that his camera was stolen. He described the plainclothes police who reportedly attacked him as a "gang of thugs," who wanted to clear the square before planned protests following Friday prayers.<ref name="ABC 16.2.2011">{{cite news | author=Ned Potter | title=Bahrain Protests: At Least 2 Dead in Crackdown; ABC's Miguel Marquez Roughed Up | date=16 February 2011 | publisher=[[ABC News]] | url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/bahrain-protests-abc-news-correspondent-miguel-marquez-beaten/story?id=12936124 | accessdate=12 January 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121032006/http://abcnews.go.com/International/bahrain-protests-abc-news-correspondent-miguel-marquez-beaten/story?id=12936124 | archivedate=21 January 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Health worker accounts=== A medical volunteer said that despite showing their identification cards police attacked ten medics at the roundabout who had offered their services.<ref name="HRW report">{{cite report |title=Targets of Retribution: Attacks against Medics, Injured Protesters, and Health Facilities |pages=14–5 |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |url=https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/bahrain0711webwcover.pdf |date=18 July 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170310051619/https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/bahrain0711webwcover.pdf |archivedate=10 March 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
For eight hours Health Minister Faisal al-Hamar prevented ambulances going to the assistance of those injured at Pearl Roundabout.<ref name="NYT 17.2.2011"/><ref name="Al wasat 3">{{cite news | script-title=ar:السماح للإسعاف بالوصول الى دوار اللؤلؤ | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527743/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220054135/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527743/1.html | archivedate=20 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Doctors and paramedics protested inside [[Salmaniya Medical Complex]] (SMC);<ref name="Al wasat 5">{{cite news | script-title=ar:الأطباء والمسعفون يطالبون الحكومة السماح لهم بمعالجة الجرحى ويهتفون "يسقط يسقط الوزير" | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527740/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220052047/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527740/1.html | archivedate=20 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> while still doing their best to help the wounded, medics signed a petition and formed a human chain calling for his resignation for "blocking ambulances from going to help those injured in Pearl Roundabout."<ref name="Al wasat 26">{{cite news |script-title=ar:الأطباء يعتصمون ويطالبون باستقالة وزير الصحة |date=18 February 2011 |work=Al-Wasat |url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527884/1.html |accessdate=13 January 2012 |language=Arabic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906094515/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527884/1.html |archivedate=6 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They claimed that he told doctors at the hospital of his resignation before leaving. However, he later rejected that claim.<ref name="Al wasat 7">{{cite news |script-title=ar:وزير الصحة ينفي استقالته |date=17 February 2011 |work=Al-Wasat |url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527744/1.html |accessdate=11 January 2012 |language=Arabic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907031616/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527744/1.html |archivedate=7 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#F8E0F7 |salign=right| quote = I've seen tens of casualties including children getting beaten by security forces. Bodies were lying on the floor and security forces prevented us from getting to them. They [police] were kicking the bodies and treating them harshly, bluntly and without any humanity.| source = ''Mohammed Ramadan'', a paramedic<ref name="Al wasat 24"/>|align=right| width=250px}}
Despite the block, Salmaniya Medical Complex's disaster plan was activated on the morning of the attack. It called for more than a dozen ambulances to search nearby areas and Pearl Roundabout. Another dozen ambulances were put on stand-by, according to a member of the medical staff. The staff said that ambulances were functioning in accordance with the plan until about 6:00 am, when an alleged call from the Ministry of Interior ordered all but two ambulances to head back to the SMC. However, this order was ignored and more ambulances were sent to search for the injured in the areas surrounding the roundabout.<ref name="HRW report"/>
About five ambulances reached Pearl Roundabout, where they were confronted by police and army forces; three drivers and nine paramedics were attacked.<ref name="NYT 17.2.2011"/> One of the injured drivers claimed that police had clubbed him and that a senior officer had told him: "If I see you again, I’ll kill you." Another ambulance driver, who was unharmed, said that police removed injured protesters from his vehicle by force<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(2)"/> and a military officer – whom he believed to be a Saudi, based on his Arabic dialect – held a gun to his head and warned him to drive away or be shot.<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011"/> One ambulance was reportedly confiscated by police, who then took it to an unknown location after beating its driver and other paramedics, who had to walk back to the SMC.<ref name="Al wasat 4">{{cite news | script-title=ar:الدكتور صادق العكري يسقط جريحا والان في غرفة العمليات ومصادرة سيارة اسعاف | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527734/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925200031/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527734/1.html | archivedate=25 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A paramedic also said police allowed the first ambulances that reached Pearl Roundabout to pass safely, while some security personnel captured videos, but when the ambulances moved out carrying casualties security forces had targeted the vehicles. He said: "Later Bahrain T.V. showed only the scenes where they allowed us to pass in order to mislead the public opinion. I personally heard orders given to security forces via their communication devices to target, threat and delay paramedics as long as they can. Security forces dealt with us as if we were defendants and partners to protesters who wanted to hide them, whereas what we were doing was a professional and humane duty that has nothing to do with our political position."<ref name="Al wasat 24">{{cite news | script-title=ar:ماذا قال المسعفون والممرضون عن يومي الخميس والجمعة الأليمين؟ | date=19 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3091/news/read/528363/1.html | accessdate=5 February 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202024245/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3091/news/read/528363/1.html | archivedate=2 December 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> When the block was lifted in the late morning till noon, paramedics did not find any casualties to take back to the SMC at Pearl Roundabout, despite seeing handcuffed protesters being stomped on by police when they arrived.<ref name="Al wasat 25">{{cite news | script-title=ar:منع سيارات الإسعاف من إنقاذ الجرحى وضرب 4 مسعفين | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527883/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907001342/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527883/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Government accounts===
{{External media | video1 = {{Youtube|KHjppYjB-Dw|Ministry of Interior spokesman Tariq Al-Hassan on Bahrain TV}} }}
The government account of the incident indicated that police, using a megaphone, had ordered protesters to evacuate the area and that some had done so, whereas others remained in defiance of the law. It added that police only intervened after exhausting all opportunities for dialogue<ref name="Al wasat 11"/> and that lethal shots were fired only at armed protesters who attacked police officers. Security forces reported finding pistols, bullets, large quantities of knives, daggers, swords and other sharp objects, as well as [[Hezbollah]] flags at the site.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/>
On a state television show, Ministry of Interior spokesman Tariq Al-Hassan said that fifty police officers had been injured, including two with serious sword wounds and that "one protester drove over police resulting in injuries including cutting-off fingers of a policeman before we could catch him." He also denied policemen prevented ambulances from reaching Pearl Roundabout or attacked any paramedics, but instead: "What happened is that protesters stole an ambulance car, so we were checking on every ambulance that reaches the roundabout."<ref name="Al wasat 18">{{cite news | script-title=ar:"الداخلية" تسرد الرواية الرسمية لفض اعتصام دوار اللؤلؤة | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527872/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906083632/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527872/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> One doctor working at SMC's [[emergency room|ER]] supported the government's account, accusing protesters of attacking the Under-Secretary-of-State for Health, taking control of all hospital entrances and stealing an ambulance.<ref name="HRW report2">{{cite report |title=Targets of Retribution: Attacks against Medics, Injured Protesters, and Health Facilities |page=16 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |url=https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/bahrain0711webwcover.pdf |date=18 July 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170310051619/https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/bahrain0711webwcover.pdf |archivedate=10 March 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry, set up by the king to report on the events of February and March, did not see any evidence to support the government's claim that protesters were armed{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=74, 230–2}} or that medics had supplied them with weapons, however it stated that medics took control of the first floor of Salmaniya hospital.<ref>{{cite news | title= Bahrain court upholds verdict in medics trial | date= 1 October 2012 | publisher= Al Jazeera | url= http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/10/201210195911177809.html | accessdate= 1 October 2012 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121003052434/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/10/201210195911177809.html | archivedate= 3 October 2012 | df= dmy-all }}</ref> Eyewitnesses also denied being warned by the police, saying that if they had known of the police presence then women and children would have been evacuated.<ref name="Al wasat 11"/>
==Aftermath==
[[File:Police standing in Pearl roundabout after it was cleared from protesters.jpg|thumb|Pearl Roundabout in the morning of the raid]] [[File:Army tanks blocking the road to Pearl roundabout.jpg|thumb|Army checkpoint near Pearl Roundabout]] [[File:Protesters chanting - Flickr - Al Jazeera English.jpg|thumb|Protesters gathering at Salmaniya hospital car parks]]
The raid culminated in the destruction of the encampment, with flattened tents and protesters' belongings scattered all over the place.<ref name="AJE 17.2.2011"/> Security forces then declared the protest camp to be illegal and installed barbed wire around Pearl Roundabout.<ref>{{cite news | author=Ned Potter | title=Riot Police Storm Bahrain Camp; 4 Reported Dead | date=17 February 2011 | agency=Associated Press | publisher=[[Ynetnews]] | url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4029898,00.html | accessdate=19 April 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220174132/http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4029898,00.html | archivedate=20 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> An hour after the attack, a number of protesters tried to return to the roundabout, which was completely controlled by police. Security forces fired a shotgun on one protester directly in the head from a few centimetres away, killing him instantly. Police claimed the protesters attacked them using "metal rods, swords, molotov cocktails, stones, and other weapons." After some more time around 500 protesters gathered in the Noaim area, but were dispersed by police.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=74, 231–2}}
Sporadic clashes broke out around Bahrain hours after the raid. During the afternoon, the [[National Guard (Bahrain)|National Guard]] deployed eight armoured vehicles{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=74}} and the Bahrain Defence Force deployed tanks and at least 50 [[armoured personnel carrier]]s armed with machine guns<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/> around the capital, [[Manama]], the first time military armoured vehicles had been seen in the streets since the protests commenced.<ref name="ABC 17.2.2011">{{cite news | author=Ned Potter | title=Police Forces Storm Bahrain Protest Camps Leaving At Least 4 Dead | date=17 February 2011 | publisher=[[ABC News]] | url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/police-forces-bahrain-protest-dead-Miguel-Marquez/story?id=12937501#.Tw9CdKX9Oos | accessdate=13 January 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107094056/http://abcnews.go.com/International/police-forces-bahrain-protest-dead-Miguel-Marquez/story?id=12937501#.Tw9CdKX9Oos | archivedate=7 November 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Military checkpoints were set up and patrols circulated throughout the country. The Interior Ministry issued a warning to citizens to stay out of the streets;<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb">{{cite news|title=Clashes Rock Bahraini Capital |date=17 February 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wZPVZfFG?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |archivedate=17 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> while the army warned people that they were ready to take "punitive measures" to restore order.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=75}} The Bahrain Defence Force issued Statement 1, which asked citizens to "distance themselves from gatherings in vital areas in the capital [to prevent] fear, shock and serious traffic disruptions."<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/><ref name="Al wasat 8">{{cite news | script-title=ar:"قيادة دفاع البحرين" تعلن انتشار قوات عسكرية في العاصمة | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527747/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220052955/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527747/1.html | archivedate=20 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Main roads leading to Manama were blocked and traffic was also redirected,<ref name="Al wasat 10">{{cite news | script-title=ar:تلفزيون البحرين يعلن عن اغلاق شارع الملك فيصل والشوارع الفرعية له | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527739/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220052945/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527739/1.html | archivedate=20 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> while main roads of the capital were almost empty,<ref>{{cite news| title=Empty roads| date=17 February 2011| publisher=Al Jazeera| url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/aljazeeraenglish/5454387988/| accessdate=15 March 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111229092329/http://www.flickr.com/photos/aljazeeraenglish/5454387988/| archivedate=29 December 2011| df=dmy-all}}</ref> as workers stayed home, leaving banks and "other key institutions" closed.<ref name="AJE 17.2.2011"/>
===Salmaniya hospital===
According to an unnamed Al Jazeera reporter<!--keep it like this till a source can be found. I've seen a source from April 2012, but there is no evidence to support this is the same reporter-->, hospitals in Manama were full because of patients that were awaiting treatment as a result of and during the police raid, including medical personnel who were attacked by police while trying to help the wounded.<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb" /> ''[[New York Times]]'' columnist [[Nicolas Kristof]] reported that "hospital corridors were also full of frantic mothers searching desperately for children who had gone missing in the attack."<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011"/> Women's cries were evident in the hospital and some fainted.<ref name="Al wasat 14">{{cite news | script-title=ar:الخميس الدامي يخلف 4 ضحايا و250 جريحاً | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527796/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906234520/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527796/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Minister of Health appeared on state television and claimed that the situation at the main hospital was calm and that there were only seven minor injuries.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=173}}
The [[blood bank]] at SMC called for blood donations, while the U.S. missionary hospital announced that it will be treating those injured for free.<ref name="Al wasat 6">{{cite news | script-title=ar:بنك الدم يعلن حاجته لمتبرعين للدم ومستشفى الارسالية الاميركية يفتح ابوابه للطوارئ مجانا | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527736/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907010923/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527736/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> An eyewitness at the hospital said: "Lots of people are standing at the gates of the hospital. The police have closed the area so that no people can get in or out – some tried to get out and were shot at by police."<ref name="bbc231injured"/> The SMC was seen as a safe place for the opposition protesters to go.<ref name="DWB report">{{cite report |title=Health Services Paralyzed: Bahrain’s Military Crackdown on Patients |publisher=[[Doctors Without Borders]] (Médecins Sans Frontières) |url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/publications/reports/2011/Bahrain_BP_Final_06042011_2106_FR-EN%20LOGO.pdf |date=7 April 2011 |page=2 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513214615/http://doctorswithoutborders.org/publications/reports/2011/Bahrain_BP_Final_06042011_2106_FR-EN%20LOGO.pdf |archivedate=13 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> By late afternoon, about 4,000 protesters had congregated at the hospital,<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(3)">{{cite news | author=Martin Chulov | title=Bahrain's quiet anger turns to rage | date=17 February 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrains-quiet-anger-turns-rage?INTCMP=SRCH | accessdate=23 January 2012 | location=London | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217151157/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrains-quiet-anger-turns-rage?INTCMP=SRCH | archivedate=17 December 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> while protesters who had gathered in the car parks near the emergency entrance{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=75}} chanted: "Down with the regime, with our blood we will defend our rights."<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(2)"/>
After seeing the violence, [[Ali al-Ghanmi]], a police officer, left his guard post and joined the crowd, announcing to them that he could no longer support "a killer institution."<ref name=BBC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-16472923 |title=Bahrain unrest: policeman jailed for joining protests |date=9 January 2012 |work=BBC News |accessdate=19 May 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326093425/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-16472923 |archivedate=26 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The crowd hoisted him on their shoulders and al-Ghanmi became an immediate "mini-celebrity" of the protest movement.<ref name=HRF>{{cite web|url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/2011/11/04/in-praise-of-a-bahraini-police-officer/ |title=In Praise of a Bahraini Police Officer |author=Brian Dooley |date=4 November 2011 |work=Human Rights First |accessdate=19 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604041131/http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/2011/11/04/in-praise-of-a-bahraini-police-officer/ |archivedate=4 June 2012 }}</ref>
==Casualties==
[[File:Surgeon Sadik Al-Ekry giving a speech at Pearl Roundabout.jpg|thumb|Plastic surgeon Sadiq Alekry giving a speech, two weeks after his injury]]
More than 300 individuals were injured during the raid,<ref name="bbc231injured"/> including women and children;<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011"/> some of them in critical condition.<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb" /><ref name="bbc231injured">{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12490286 | title = Bahrain Protests: Police Break Up Pearl Square Crowd | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 17 February 2011 | accessdate = 15 April 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110405191818/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12490286 | archivedate = 5 April 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> Injured protesters were taken to the Salmaniya Medical Complex, many of them with broken limbs and open wounds.<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(3)"/> Four individuals were killed by police using [[Birdshot|shotguns]], from close range. While two of them who were shot in the back, another protester was shot in the thigh and subsequently died at the SMC;{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=230–2}} the fourth was shot in the head later and died instantly.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=74, 231–2}} At least 25,000 mourners took part at the funeral procession, which was held in [[Sitra]] on 18 February for the three protesters originating from the island.<ref name="AJE LB 18.2.2011">{{cite news | title = Al Jazeera Live Blog 18 February | date = 18 February 2011 | publisher = Al Jazeera | url = http://blogs.aljazeera.com/middle-east/2011/02/16/live-blog-bahrain#feb18 | accessdate = 17 January 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120501071021/http://blogs.aljazeera.com/middle-east/2011/02/16/live-blog-bahrain#feb18 | archivedate = 1 May 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Al wasat 29">{{cite news | script-title=ar:علام البحرين تلف جثمان "المؤمن" في سترة .. والآلاف تشيعه لمقبرة "الخارجية" | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527896/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906090216/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527896/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
;Dr Sadiq Alekry
Dr Sadiq Alekry, a 44-year-old plastic surgeon, voluntarily offered his services at the roundabout on the evening of 16 February, shortly after he had returned from [[Houston]].<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011"/> According to [[Human rights watch]], Alekry along with other staff were wearing special medical jackets showing the [[Red Crescent]].<ref name="HRW report"/> During the raid, riot police attacked his tent and cut through it;<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(3)"/> despite telling them he was a physician,<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011"/> police handcuffed him from his back and a number of security officers repeatedly punched, kicked and hit him with sticks on his head and other parts of the body.<ref name="HRW report"/><ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(3)"/>
About 20 officers then marched him away from Pearl Roundabout. Alekry said that while walking him, riot police also broke his nose and damaged his left eye so badly in the process that he temporarily lost his sight.<ref name="HRW report"/><ref name="Al wasat 24-2">{{cite news | script-title=ar:العكري: رأيت الموت أمام عيني في "دوار اللؤلؤة" | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527882/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907000427/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527882/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> He was then taken to a police bus, where his pants were pulled down by an officer who threatened Alekry with sexual assault; though the threat was not carried out.<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011"/><ref name="HRW report"/>
In the bus, Alekry's shirt was pulled over his head and, while he was still hand-cuffed, security officers continued kicking and beating him for about an hour, until he fell to the floor. Nevertheless, the beating continued and Alekry reported that a police officer told him: "If you bleed in my chair with your dirty blood I will beat you to death!" When an ambulance arrived, police allowed him and three other detainees to be taken to hospital. He arrived at the SMC at 6:00 am, with severe injuries to his back, chest and face and underwent facial surgery a few days later.<ref name="HRW report"/>
===Deaths===
;Ali Ahmed Moumen
[[File:A painting for Ali al-Mo'men.JPG|thumb|Portrait in memorial of Ali Moumen]]
Ali Ahmed Moumen was a 22-year-old college senior<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/> who died at the SMC on 17 February after being shot by a police in the thigh.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=232–3}}<ref name="hrw-deaths"/> His death certificate indicated he died due to "extensive bleeding leading to intractable hypovolemic shock."<ref name="AJE 20.2.2011"/> Hours before his death he had posted a "status" update on ''[[Facebook]]'' saying: "My blood is sacrificed for my country."<ref name="Al Wasat 37">{{cite news | script-title=ar:دمي فداء لوطني... "الفيسبوك" يسجل كلمات الشهيد "المؤمن" الأخيرة | date=20 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528125/1.html | accessdate=23 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906234055/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528125/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> That night, Moumen was sleeping beside his younger brother and made it out of Pearl Roundabout safely, but, according to his father, was then killed when he tried to return<ref name="Al Wasat 37"/> after hearing women and children were trapped. One of his friends said Ali was "shot in the street and merely left to die."<ref name="AJE 20.2.2011"/>
Moumen was picked up at around 8:30 from Pearl Roundabout. He had serious injuries to his pelvis and right thigh. Bleeding profusely, two paramedics found Moumen after police allowed them through. The paramedics reported that they saw another possibly dead body with a fractured skull close to Moumen's, but were not permitted to pick it up. While leaving, the ambulance was reportedly attacked by riot police who beat the driver before allowing them to continue to the SMC. At the emergency room, Moumen had a surgery, but he died at 9:30.<ref name="HRW report3">{{cite report |title=Targets of Retribution: Attacks against Medics, Injured Protesters, and Health Facilities |page=18 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |url=https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/bahrain0711webwcover.pdf |date=18 July 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170310051619/https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/bahrain0711webwcover.pdf |archivedate=10 March 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> His father called Prime Minister [[Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa]] a "killer" and blamed him for his son's death.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011">{{cite news | title = After crackdown, army makes show of force in Bahrain's capital | date = 18 February 2011 | publisher = [[CNN]] | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/17/bahrain.protests/ | accessdate = 13 January 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110628193200/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/17/bahrain.protests/ | archivedate = 28 June 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> An unnamed policeman who charged with the murder of Moumen was acquitted on 27 September 2012.<ref name="policemen-acquitted">{{cite news | title = Jail for Bahrain cop who killed protester| date=27 September 2012 | publisher=Perth Now | agency =[[Australian Associated Press]] | url = http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/breaking-news/jail-for-bahrain-cop-who-killed-protester/story-e6frg13l-1226482997608 | accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref>
;Ali Mansoor Khudair
Ali Mansour Ahmed Khudair was a 53 or 58-year-old Bahraini who died on 17 February after police shot at his back.<ref name="hrw-deaths"/>{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=231}} He had 91 pellets in his chest.<ref name="NYT 17.2.2011"/> Khudair was a fisherman from Sitra who lived in a ramshackle house. He had three sons: Hassan (21), Jaffar (14) and Ahmed (9), as well as an 18-year-old daughter. Jaffar said: "I was with my father in Pearl Roundabout when they attacked. We were asleep at first, when I woke up, I started moving away, but my father told me to endure, stay and not fear. Then we heard screams and rushed there. For a few seconds he spoke to the security forces, asking them to stay away from women and children, but they shot him in the chest. He fell to the ground and I couldn't see him after tear gas cloud covered the place."<ref name="Al Wasat 35">{{cite news | script-title=ar:أبناء الشهيد خضير: دفن والدنا وحقه لن يدفن معه | date=20 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528123/1.html | accessdate=23 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906083637/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528123/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
;Mahmood Makki Abutaki
Mahmoud Makki Abutaki was a 22-year-old college student majoring in engineering,<ref name="Al Wasat 36">{{cite news |script-title=ar:قبلة الموت تعلن رحيل الشهيد محمود |date=20 February 2011 |work=Al-Wasat |url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528124/1.html |accessdate=23 January 2012 |language=Arabic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906143303/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528124/1.html |archivedate=6 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> when he died on 17 February after being shot in the back by police.<ref name="hrw-deaths"/>{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=230–1}} Medics pulled about 200 pellets of birdshot from his chest and arms.<ref name="NYT 17.2.2011"/> Abutaki's elder brother, Ahmed, who was in the morgue while holding his brothers' hands, recalled the last conversation they had the previous night for the media present: "He said, 'This is my chance, to have a say, so that maybe our country will do something for us.' My country did do something; it killed him."<ref name="NYT 17.2.2011"/>
;Isa Abdulhasan Ali Hussain
Isa Abdulhasan Ali Hussain was a 60-year-old Bahraini who died on 17 February morning immediately after riot police fired at his head from point-blank range.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=231–2}}<ref name="hrw-deaths">{{cite report |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2011/03/29/bahrain-investigate-deaths-linked-crackdown |date=29 March 2011 |accessdate=7 January 2012 |title=Bahrain: Investigate Deaths Linked to Crackdown |publisher=Human Rights Watch |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125171850/http://www.hrw.org/news/2011/03/29/bahrain-investigate-deaths-linked-crackdown |archivedate=25 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Hussain was a part of a group of protesters who marched back towards Pearl Roundabout after being dispersed when police shot him. Eyewitnesses say he went near security forces asking them to allow young people help the injured protesters.<ref name="NYT 17.2.2011"/><ref name="Al wasat 28">{{cite news | script-title=ar:"ساعدوا الجرحى رحم الله والديكم"... آخر كلمات الشهيد عيسى | date=20 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528126/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907043827/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3089/news/read/528126/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, police claimed he was with a group of protesters who attacked them using metal rods, swords, molotov cocktails, stones and other weapons.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=74, 231–2}} His funeral was held on 18 February in [[Karzakan]] and was attended by thousands of mourners.<ref name="Al wasat 28"/> An unnamed policeman charged with his murder was acquitted on 27 September 2012.<ref name="policemen-acquitted"/>
==Responses==
===Domestic=== ;Executive
King [[Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa]] praised the concluding statement from the meeting of the [[Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf]] foreign ministers, which was held on 17 February in Manama, and offered "full support" for Bahrain's security and politically, economically and defensively.<ref name="Al wasat 17">{{cite news | script-title=ar:العاهل يشيد بالبيان الختامي لاجتماع وزراء خارجية التعاون | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527799/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906185235/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527799/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> At a news conference, Foreign Minister [[Khalid ibn Ahmad Al Khalifah]] alleged, and expressed his surprise, that protesters had attacked police.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/> When asked about the reasons for choosing a pre-dawn time for the raid, he said: "The reason for choosing this time was the smaller number of participants, and this reduces injuries." He called the deaths of the three protestors during the raid a "regrettable accident. Police action was necessary to pull Bahrain back from the brink of a sectarian abyss."<ref name="AJE LB 17.2.2011"/> During the press conference, which was broadcasting live on national television, ''Al-Wasat'' correspondent Reem Khalifa cried tears and described what happened as a "real massacre."<ref name="Al wasat 16">{{cite news | script-title=ar:وزير الخارجية: لا أزمة ثقة بين الحكومة والشعب... وقادرون على تجاوز المحنة | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527798/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906190415/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527798/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In what ''Al-Wasat'' called "an unexpected move," [[Crown Prince]] [[Salman bin Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa]] appeared on state-owned television to express his condolences to the people for the "hard days" and asked them to "calm down." He offered open dialogue with political societies, shortly before a [[royal decree]] was issued by his father, King Hamad, commissioning Salman to lead the dialogue.<ref name="Al wasat 30">{{cite news | script-title=ar:ولي العهد يطلق مبادرة للتهدئة والحوار مع الجميع | date=19 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527967/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906073848/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527967/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
;Legislative
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#F3F0FD |salign=right| quote = If the government had any evidence to prove protesters attacked security forces with [[white arms]], they'd have shown it already.| source = ''[[Abdul Jalil Khalil]]'', [[Al Wefaq]]<ref name="Al wasat 20">{{cite news | script-title=ar:خليل يتحدى الإعلام الرسمي بعرض صورة الضحية عبدالحسن | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527874/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906075617/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527874/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>|align=right| width=250px}}
All 18 [[Member of Parliament|MPs]] from [[Al Wefaq]], the only opposition political party represented in [[Council of Representatives of Bahrain|parliament]], submitted their resignations.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=75}} They announced that the investigation committee formed by the king to fact-find the issues into the previous two killing incidents was only for [[public relations|media consumption]], more so in the light of the deaths of four more protesters. They said the extraordinary session of parliament was illegal according to its rules of procedure.<ref name="Al wasat 15">{{cite news | script-title=ar:"الوفاق" تنسحب "كلياً ونهائياً" من مجلس النواب | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527797/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907035836/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527797/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Al Wefaq described the government account as a "silly play that wasn't even as good as the previously exposed plays." It considered the report, which published photographs of firearms, swords and daggers, as "funny" and that these tools were not commercially sold in Bahrain.<ref name="Al wasat 19">{{cite news | script-title=ar:"الوفاق" تصف المعلومات التي أوردتها "الداخلية" بـ "المسرحية" | date=18 February 2011 | work=[[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al-Wasat]] | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527873/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906085340/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527873/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Ali Salman]], the head of Al Wefaq, said the party would continue to demand reform.<ref name="Al wasat 34">{{cite news | script-title=ar:الحاج عيسى يودِّع الأرض التي رواها بدمه | date=19 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527974/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907004516/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527974/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Abdul Jalil Khalil]], an Al Wefaq member of parliament, described the raid as "real terrorism. Whoever took the decision to attack the protest was aiming to kill."<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb" /> He also said the casualty number is proportially large given the [[Demographics of Bahrain|small size of Bahrain's population]] and added: "After what happened today, people are asking us to leave parliament. Quit the government."<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/> Other Al Wefaq MP's and lawyers made a criminal complaint against senior officials of the Ministry of Interior, including its minister, the agents, the commander of public security forces, his assistants and the various heads of security zones.<ref name="Al wasat 21">{{cite news | script-title=ar:محامون ونواب وفاقيون يبلغون جنائيّاً ضد مسئولي وزارة الداخلية | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527877/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907045535/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527877/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
;Political Seven [[Opposition (Bahrain)|opposition political parties]], including Al Wefaq and the [[National Democratic Action Society]], issued a joint statement rejecting the government's charge that the demonstrators were armed and condemning "the heinous massacre" perpetrated by police, including the prevention of ambulances from reaching the site to ferry the wounded to hospital. They demanded the resignation of the government and the formation of a new one to investigate the "crime" and submit political reforms.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|p=75}}<ref name="Al wasat 13">{{cite news | script-title=ar:قوى سياسية وأهلية تدين استخدام الـقوة في تفريق "اعتصام دوار اللؤلؤة" | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527795/1.html | accessdate=12 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907043817/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527795/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Ibrahim Sharif]], the head of National Democratic Action Society and a [[Sunni Islam|Sunni Muslim]], said protesters were not given enough time to evacuate the area and that government could have told them hours before or even by small papers thrown from helicopters.<ref name="Al wasat 20"/> He told the ''[[BBC]]'' that "throughout the day there were rumours we would have another 24 hours, but the attack has come without [any] warning."<ref name="bbc231injured"/>
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#F8E0F7 |salign=right| quote = Talking about Hezbollah flags is only for the sake of public opinion so that they can call this movement sectarian and pro-Iranian.| source = ''[[Ibrahim Sharif]]'', Sunni opposition figure<ref name="Al wasat 20"/>|align=right| width=250px}}
;Other The [[General Federation of Workers Trade Unions in Bahrain]] condemned the use of force in breaking up the peaceful gathering at Pearl Roundabout and asked King Hamad to intervene to stop security forces' violence and to punish those responsible for the incidents. They also announced that a meeting of the Central Council and heads of other trade unions is in the state of permanent session to take any deemed necessary steps, including the call for a [[general strike]].<ref name="Al wasat 13"/> The Bahrain Teachers’ Society called for a strike and gatherings outside schools on 20 February.{{sfn|BICI report|M. Cherif Bassiouni|Nigel S. Rodley|Philippe Kirsch|2011|pp=75–6}} The [[Bahrain Human Rights Society]] and 18 other civil society foundations condemned the "sudden brutal attack" and asked other international and Arab figures to condemn it.<ref name="Al wasat 13"/>
[[Isa Qassim|Ayatollah Isa Qassim]], Bahrain's highest-ranking Shia cleric,<ref>{{cite news| author=Robin Wigglesworth and Simeon Kerr |title= Bahrain clamps down on revolt | date=17 March 2011 | work=[[Financial Times]]| url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/ea003042-4ffd-11e0-9ad1-00144feab49a.html#axzz2AqKX4uL6| accessdate= 31 October 2012}}</ref> described the incident as a "massacre" in [[Friday sermon]]'s ''[[Khutbah]]'': "This reckless murder, and thirst to kill would create a complete break between the government and the people, and it will not allow any chance of any vote aiming to calm the situation and heal the wounds."<ref name="Al wasat 33">{{cite news | script-title=ar:قاسم: مجزرة "دوار اللؤلؤة" تعبر عن مدى الاستخفاف بدم الشعب | date=19 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527972/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907040208/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527972/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> A group of clerics including the head of the [[Olama council]] visited the wounded at the SMC and spoke of their support for the protesters' demands and also called for immediate political reforms.<ref name="Al wasat 27">{{cite news | script-title=ar:جمع من رجال الدين توافدوا إلى "السلمانية" وزاروا الجرحى | date=18 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527885/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907020800/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3087/news/read/527885/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Olama council described the raid as a "terrible crime and at least a massacre" and asked for immediate urgent initiatives to achieve the "just demands of the people. We refuse blank prosthetic solutions, the practice of wasting time, and referral to the powerless Parliament that lacks popular legitimacy."<ref name="Al wasat 31">{{cite news | script-title=ar:توالي ردود الفعل المنددة باستخدام القوة المفرطة تجاه المواطنين | date=19 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527969/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907003218/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527969/1.html | archivedate=7 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Doctors, nurses and paramedics organised a [[sit-in]] at the parks of the SMC demanding the resignation of the health minister and condemning the blocking of ambulances from going to Pearl Roundabout.<ref name="Al wasat 32">{{cite news | script-title=ar:الأطباء يعتصمون مطالبين وزير الصحة بالاستقالة ويعلنون تضامنهم مع الشعب | date=19 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527971/1.html | accessdate=13 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906075622/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3088/news/read/527971/1.html | archivedate=6 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Bahrain Medical Society and Bahrain Dental Society issued a joint statement denouncing the "unjustified and excessive use of force by police, and the banning of medical teams from performing their duties" and asked the king to take immediate action to stop these procedures from re-occurring.<ref name="Al wasat 9">{{cite news | script-title=ar:بيان طارئ جمعية الأطباء البحرينية وجمعية أطباء الفم والأسنان البحرينية | date=17 February 2011 | work=Al-Wasat | url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527745/1.html | accessdate=11 January 2012 | language=Arabic | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220052007/http://www.alwasatnews.com/3086/news/read/527745/1.html | archivedate=20 February 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===International=== ;Supranational bodies
The [[United Nations]] [[Secretary-General of the United Nations#Secretaries-General|Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] asked for bringing to justice those responsible for the violence. He expressed his deep concern and disturbance "by the violent means used to disperse demonstrators."<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/><ref name="Al wasat 22"/> A spokesperson for [[Catherine Ashton]], the [[European Union]]'s [[High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy|High Representative]], said that she was very concerned about the events that took place and that she expressed regret for the deaths and acts of violence, while also calling on the Bahraini government to respect and protect the basic rights of its citizens including the right to assemble peacefully. "Concerns expressed by the people must be addressed peacefully through dialogue."<ref name="Al wasat 22"/>
;States
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#F8E0F7 |salign=right| quote = In light of events we are today formally reviewing recent licensing decisions for exports to Bahrain. We will urgently revoke licences if we judge that they are no longer in line with the criteria.| source = ''[[Alistair Burt]]'', a British minister<ref name="AJE LB 17.2.2011"/><ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011(4)">{{cite news | author=[[Peter Beaumont (journalist)|Peter Beaumont]] and Robert Booth | title=Bahrain uses UK-supplied weapons in protest crackdown | date=17 February 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrain-crackdown-uk-arms-sales | accessdate=17 January 2012 | location=London | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921064605/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrain-crackdown-uk-arms-sales | archivedate=21 September 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> |align=right| width=250px}}
French Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Christine Valle expressed regret for the excessive use of force in several Arab countries and serious concern about the recent developments in Bahrain, as well as Libya and Yemen, in particular.<ref name="Al wasat 22"/> German [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Germany)|Foreign Minister]] [[Guido Westerwelle]] condemned the use of violence by the police and called on officials in Bahrain to stop the use of violence immediately and protect the protesters better. "They [protestors] are just exercising their rights."<ref name="Al wasat 22"/> [[Saudi Arabia]]n prince [[Talal bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Talal Bin Abdulaziz]], father of prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal|Al Waleed Bin Talal]], said there is a chance protests in Bahrain would move into Saudi Arabia if serious reforms were not carried out.<ref name="AJE LB 17.2.2011"/> [[United Arab Emirates]] Foreign Minister [[Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] expressed his country's support for Bahrain, stressing that what affects Bahrain and its security would affect the entire Gulf Cooperation Council and ultimately all countries of the world.<ref name="Al wasat 17"/>
{{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#F3F0FD |salign=right| quote = We call on restraint from the government, to keep its commitment to hold accountable those who have utilized excessive force against peaceful demonstrators, and we urge a return to a process that will result in real, meaningful changes for the people there.| source = ''[[Hillary Clinton]]'', U.S. Secretary of State<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/><ref name="Al wasat 22"/> |align=right| width=250px}}
[[United Kingdom]] [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] said that he was "deeply concerned" by the "unacceptable violence" used against protesters.<ref>{{cite news | date = 19 February 2011 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12514696 | title = Hague Condemns Violence in Libya, Bahrain and Yemen | publisher = BBC News | accessdate = 21 April 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110405190549/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12514696 | archivedate = 5 April 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> He also stressed the "need for peaceful action to address the concerns of protesters" to his Bahraini counterpart.<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011"/> The U.K. government then announced that in light of the unrest it has decided to revoke some arms export licenses to Bahrain stating that "licenses will not be issued when officials judge that there is a risk that the exports may provoke regional or internal conflicts or be used to facilitate internal repression."<ref>{{cite web | title = Bahrain Forces Fire at Protesters – Troops Open Live Fire Around Pearl Roundabout in Manama After Nightfall, At Least 66 Wounded | ''New York Times'' columnist Nicolas Kristof described the raid as "brutal repression" that is usually "confined to remote and backward nations" and referred to the government's version of events as "preposterous" and expressed his sadness over the events.<ref name="NYT NK 17.2.2011">{{cite news | author=[[Nicolas Kristof]] | title=Blood Runs Through the Streets of Bahrain | date=6 January 2012 | publisher=[[New York Times]] | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/18/opinion/18kristof.html | accessdate=17 January 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114044941/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/18/opinion/18kristof.html | archivedate=14 January 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Fareed Zakaria]], ''[[CNN]]''{{'}}s international affairs analyst, said that the crackdown on the protesters was a "rash move that will enrage many of its people and cost the regime international prestige. This is a terrible mistake and they will pay a heavy price for it. The regime in Bahrain is doing something very rash and unwise; it is trying to respond by using force and punitive measures. This is not going to work in the end."<ref name="CNN 18.2.2011(3)">{{cite news | author=[[Fareed Zakaria]] | title=Bahrain will pay heavy price for crackdown | date=18 February 2011 | publisher=CNN | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/OPINION/02/18/zakaria.bahrain.mideast/index.html | accessdate=14 January 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308023942/http://edition.cnn.com/2011/OPINION/02/18/zakaria.bahrain.mideast/index.html | archivedate=8 March 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Analysis==
The events at the Pearl Roundabout and Salmaniyya Medical Complex marked a turning point in the Bahraini uprising, according to the media; an analysis by ''[[The Guardian]]'' said it reduced, if not killed, any chance of dialogue.<ref name="Guardian 17.2.2011">{{cite news | author=[[Abdulnabi Alekry]] | title=Bahrain crackdown will make citizens more determined | date=17 February 2011 | publisher=The Guardian | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/feb/17/bahrain-egypt-political-change?INTCMP=SRCH | accessdate=17 January 2012 | location=London | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309184320/http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/feb/17/bahrain-egypt-political-change?INTCMP=SRCH | archivedate=9 March 2016 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The raid expanded the demands of some protesters from asking for reforms which included writing a new [[Constitution of Bahrain|constitution]] to calling for an end to the monarchy.<ref name="guard_downwiththeking">{{cite news|title=Bahrain Mourners Call for End to Monarchy |date=18 February 2011 |agency=Associated Press |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-mourners-call-downnfall-monarchy |accessdate=31 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5waOzlomm?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-mourners-call-downnfall-monarchy |archivedate=18 February 2011 |deadurl=no |location=London |df= }}</ref> According to the ''[[Bahrain Mirror]]'', the phrase "after Thursday, we stopped the talking; the people want to overthrow the regime" ([[Arabic]]: من بعد الخميس أنهينا الكلام، الشعب يريد إسقاط النظام) became popular in later protests.<ref name="BH Mirror 2.1.2012">{{cite news|script-title=ar:ائتلاف ثورة 14 فبراير سيرة مختصرة |date=6 January 2012 |publisher=[[Bahrain Mirror]] |url=http://www.bahrainmirror.org/article.php?id=2643&cid=117 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130414065659/http://www.bahrainmirror.org/article.php?id=2643&cid=117 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 April 2013 |accessdate=17 January 2012 |language=Arabic }}</ref> On 22 February, a mass rally dubbed the [[March of loyalty to martyrs]] was held in honour of the four protesters who had lost their lives during the day; over 100,000 people took part in the protest.<ref name="Independent 22.2.2011">{{cite news | title = Bahrain king orders release of political prisoners | date = 22 February 2011 | agency = Associated Press | work = The Independent | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/bahrain-king-orders-release-of-political-prisoners-2222371.html | accessdate = 7 July 2012 | location = London | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110227092113/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/bahrain-king-orders-release-of-political-prisoners-2222371.html | archivedate = 27 February 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> The [[Al Jazeera English]] documentary ''[[Bahrain: Shouting in the Dark]]'' also features the events of the day.
